title: Protocol for Co-culture of Microglia with Axons
procedures:
Step-By-Step Method Details
Step-By-Step Method Details
Culture of Microglia
Timing: for steps 1–14, 60–90 min; for steps 15–17, 14 days
This protocol can be adapted for use in culturing microglia (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). Time course for the collection of microglia depends on the number of cells and the number of experimental groups. Scarify mice after intraperitoneal administration (10 mL / kg body weight) of anesthesia with a mixture of butorphanol (Vetorphale®, 0.5 mg/mL), midazolam, (Dormicum®, 0.4 mg/mL), and medetomidine (Domitor®, 0.03 mg/mL) dissolved in sterilized water. Chop the brain region of interest immediately following euthanasia. The brain and/or chunks should be kept on ice throughout the process. Older pups (~postnatal day 7), as well as newborn pups, could be used to prepare microglia. However, newborn pups (~postnatal day 3) could provide a better yield in the number of microglia (Bordt et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Lian et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). Here, we use postnatal day 3 pups.

Figure 1. Workflow of Co-culture with Microglia and Axons
Aliquot 9 mL of PBS into 50 mL tubes and cool on ice. Keep all dissecting tools cool on ice.
Dissect the brain region of interest and chop up with cold fine scissors or blades until no tissue lumps remain. Collect into the prepared 9 mL of ice cold PBS. (Schildge et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]).
Note: If you are dissecting more than five brains use separate tubes
Add 1 mL of 2.5% trypsin/PBS (final concentration 0.25%) and 50 μL of 50 mg/mL DNase into each tube.
Incubate for 15 min in a water bath at 37°C.
Critical: Agitate tubes every 5 min to mix tissue.
Add 10 mL of DMEM/10% FBS solution into each tube (equal volume of enzyme mix).
Mix by pipette (approximately 20 times) using a 10 mL disposable pipette.

Critical: Proper pipetting is important for cell viability. To avoid air bubbles, pipet up and down while leaving 0.5–1 mL of cell suspension in the disposable pipette each time. See Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Centrifuge at 180 × g (RCF) for 5 min at 4°C with max acceleration and brake.
Discard the supernatant. Add 10 mL of DMEM /10% FBS solution and resuspend cell suspension by gently pipetting.
Place a 70 μm filter mesh on top of a new 50 mL tube and filter samples by gravity flow.
Centrifuge the flow-through at 180 × g for 5 min at 4°C with max acceleration and brake.
If the supernatant is cloudy, repeat resuspension and centrifugation (Salazar et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]) .
Discard the supernatant. Add 10 mL of DMEM/10% FBS solution and resuspend cell suspension by gently pipetting.
Count the number of cells and seed them at 5 × 105 cells / mL placing up to 4 mL in a 6-cm dish (2 × 106 cells per plate).
Incubate the cells in 5% CO2 at 37°C
Replace the medium on days 1, 2, 4, and 6 with 4 mL of fresh DMEM/10% FBS solution to remove debris and floating cells.
On days 9 and 12, add 0.5–1 mL of fresh DMEM/10% FBS solution.
For issues with microglial viability, please see Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
On day 14, collect microglia from supernatant and co-culture with the axons. Proceed to step 34 for detailed steps of microglia collection.
Axon Isolation Culture
Timing For Steps 18–33: 60–70 min
Using axon isolation culture devices, axons were separately cultured from the cell bodies of the cortical neurons. Here, we used embryonic mice (E17) to prepare cortical neurons. Neonatal mice (~P3) can be used for the culture of cortical neurons. However, older mice tend to provide lower number of cells.

Prepare the axon culture device (AXISTM Axon Isolation Device, Merck; Neuron Device, Xona Microfluidics) following manufacturer’s protocol. Please refer to “Preparation of axon culture device” section for additional details (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 2. General Setup of the Axon Isolation Culture Device
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/186-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Schematic Images of Axon Isolation Culture
Neurites grow from the somal side (pale blue) toward the axonal side (yellow) and go through the microgroove.
Critical: Do NOT use expired devices.
Add 9 mL of PBS into 50 mL tubes and cool on ice. Keep all dissecting tools cool on ice.
Dissect the cortex and chop up with cold fine scissor or blades until no tissue lumps remain. Collect into the prepared 9 mL of ice cold PBS.
Add 1 mL of 2.5% trypsin (final concentration 0.25%) and 100 μL of 50 mg/mL DNase into each tube .
Incubate in a water bath at 37°C for 15 min.
Critical: Agitate tubes every 5 min to mix tissue.
Add 10 mL of DMEM/10% FBS solution into each tube (equal volume of enzyme mix).
Centrifuge at 180 × g for 4 min at 4°C with max acceleration and brake.
Discard the supernatant, then add 10 mL of DMEM/10% FBS solution.
Mix by pipette (approximately 10 times) using a 10 mL disposable pipette tip.
Critical: Proper pipetting is important for cell viability. To avoid air bubbles, pipet up and down while leaving 0.5–1 mL of cell suspension in the pipette each time.
Place a 70 μm filter mesh on top of a fresh 50 mL tube and filter the cell suspension by gravity flow.
Centrifuge the flow-through at 180 × g for 4 min at 4°C, with max acceleration and brake.
If the supernatant is cloudy, repeat resuspension and centrifugation.

Discard the supernatant. Add 10 mL of neuron culture medium, and resuspend the cell pellet by gently pipetting.
Count the number of the cells, and seed 5 μL of cell suspension (5 × 106 cells per mL) according to the manufacturer’s protocol.
Incubate the cells in 5% CO2 at 37°C
In approximately one week, neurites grow from the somal side toward the axonal side through the microgrooves (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
For issues with neuronal viability, please see Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Co-culture of Microglia with Axons
Timing For Steps 34–41: 60–90 min
Microglia are collected from the supernatant and added to the cultured axons.
On day 14 of microglia culture, collect microglia from supernatant and co-culture with the axons. To collect microglia, collect all the conditioned culture media from microglia culture dishes into fresh 50 mL tubes.
Add 0.5 mL of fresh microglia culture media to the culture dishes.
Tap the dishes and gently apply the 0.5 mL media to wash the cell layer and collect any remaining microglia. Collect the supernatant including floating cells, and add to the same 50 mL tubes containing media collected at step 34.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C with max acceleration and brake.
The remaining cells in the pellet are microglia. Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cells in 1–5 mL of neuron culture medium. Reconstituting at a high density of cells could be better since it allows you to dilute cells at an identical density after the cell counts.
Carefully remove the silicon-based axon culture device from the dish (Methods Video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Critical: Using an inverted microscope (CKX41, Olympus, or other), verify that axons kept along the microgroove line (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).

Figure 4. Depiction of a Successful or Failed Axon Isolation Culture
GFP-expressing axons after device removal. When the axons are properly cultured along the microgroove, the line of axons are easily detected (left). In contrast, when the axon culture or device removal fail, the lines of axons are broken (right). Scale bar, 20 μm.
Seed microglia into an axon isolated culture dish at 1–2 × 104 cells /cm2.
Incubate the cells in 5% CO2 at 37°C for 6 h.
Immunostaining
Timing For Steps 42–52: 1.5–2 days
Visualize microglia and axons by immunofluorescent staining.
Remove the culture medium with a pipette.
Note: Do NOT use aspirator to remove the medium.
Fix the cells with 4% Paraformaldehyde/PBS at room temperature (20°C–25°C, RT) for 30 min, without shaking.
Wash with PBS three times, each time for 5 min at RT, while gently shaking.
Blocking: Remove PBS and add Blocking solution containing 0.1% Triton X-100, 5% BSA in PBS.
Incubate at RT for 1 h while gently shaking.
Remove the blocking solution and add primary antibodies such as anti-CD11b (alternatively, anti-Iba1) and anti-tau, diluted in blocking solution (1:1,000).
Incubate at 4°C, overnight (12–24 h) while gently shaking.
Wash with PBS three times, each time for 5 min at RT, while gently shaking.
Remove the PBS and add secondary antibodies diluted in 5% BSA in PBS (1:1,000).
Wash with PBS three times, each time for 5 min at RT, while gently shaking.
Mount with mounting medium and coverslip with appropriately sized glass covers.
For issues with immunofluorescent staining, please see Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
